entry.content:
I'm using Browser sync mainly for synchronizing my bookmarks between my PC and notebook. I identified that the problem of deleting my bookmarks wasn't directly caused by Google Browser Sync, but was due to some strange error on the Firefox installation of my PC. Therefore, when starting Firefox on my PC, all the bookmarks were deleted with the effect that Browser sync reflected that deletion also on my notebook. That was the cause, so please verify that everything is fine with your Firefox installations on all your machines that are involved in the Browser sync process.
Any other experiences and comments are welcome.

entry.content: I encountered a similar problem when using the XmlSerializer of c#. There you get an error at runtime which tells you that you must provice an empty constructor. For me it makes also sense, that the serializers want an empty constructor; because I think first they create an object of the needed type (here is the empty constructor needed because there are no parameters available) and then they fill in the properties with reflection.

The problem here with the GWT was the strange message ("Type [yourpackagename.classname] was not serializable and has no concrete serializable subtypes") which was completely nonsense in my case since I implemented the IsSerializable interface. Later I've also found a bug-report on the GWT toolkit that someone requested to throw a more meaningful message but it seems as if they have not implemented it yet.

entry.title: > It seems as if the serialization process need...
entry.content:
> It seems as if the serialization process needs an empty constructor.

Uumm, yes, of course. That's a requirement put forth by the specification of java.io.Serializable: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/io/Serializable.html. If you think about it it makes a lot of sense. Otherwise, serializable class cannot be instantiated via reflection automatically - only if you know which constructor argument is which.

entry.title:
Hi,
I see your point. Well in principle I would...
entry.content:
Hi,
I see your point. Well in principle I would say that if these settings are related to the environment where the application resides (e.g. dev, staging, production) then it would also make sense to have them in a different file.
But of course I completely agree with you when you say that if you open the web.config that you immediately want to see all of the configuration at a glance and not follow links to references setting files. Also having different configuration files is somewhat dangerous since it quickly may become nasty and difficult to maintain. The less config files you have the better it is.
The risk you have with the single, "manually managed" web.config is just that you may make changes locally, commit it to the repository, but then your team colleague publishes the app the next morning, without having recognized your changes..

From a "correctness" point of view I would say that having environment-related settings in different files would make sense, however I think it also very much depends on ones specific needs and also preferences.

entry.title: There are different controls. For the one where I ...
entry.content:
There are different controls. For the one where I intended using cloning (was a 1st approach to make it work) was a server control which was initially developed by Stoffi. The control is basically an abstraction of a repeater control that lets you specify somehow declaratively the bindings of the columns and a list of available actions. The rendering of the actions has been done by rendering at runtime a Button, ImageButton or whatever, basically creating a new instance of the desired control and then adding it to the RepeaterItem (the row) in the last column.

Till now the "Action" control was just for declaring..let's call it.. some metadata for the finally rendered control. But since they are used now on many different controls where there is also the need for declaring "actions", I thought of providing different kind of actions directly rather than having to map them at runtime to the more specific controls (button, link etc..). This would give more flexibility on the user (programmer) side since one could specify an ActionLink or ActionButton, depending on his specific needs. But of course, these declarations of an ActionLink or whatever need to be duplicated for each row of the RepeaterItem (before, always new instances of a button, link... have been created).

It's difficult to explain :). I'm not sure whether you got the idea. The cloning was a first approach, but I didn't yet have the time to really try it out in deep (due to some other things which were more urgent for now). When I've time, I'll find a solution and maybe post it here if it's relevant.

entry.title:
Generally #region are used in 3 levels.
1) In a s...
entry.content:
Generally #region are used in 3 levels.

1) In a single file if you have more than one non-nested class (also enum, struct etc…), individual classes are grouped with region.
2) With in a class, some related functions or type are grouped, specially nested classes (also enum, struct, etc…), Members, ctors, properties, methods are grouped. Or single public function with its own exclusive private functions is grouped.
3) In a very large function different logical parts of the code can be grouped (our UI team has one function with switch case > 8000 cases; more than 20kLoc).
Every case should be discussed with their own aspects. In my opinion "regions are pregnant with refractoring".

entry.title: I don't have a solution for you, but looking a...
entry.content: I don't have a solution for you, but looking at the API docs, its clear that a MapView is not a subclass of View but rather it is a subclass of ViewGroup. This is the reason it won't respond to events in the same way as other views. MapView wants to consume most UI events as a means of driving its standardised map navigation. I think the clue to solving your problem is looking at what MapView's default long touch event behaviour is and then either disabling it and forwarding the event to your own handler, or alternately overriding that behaviour. You may have to dig a bit deeper into MapView.

Well, first, both Button and Hyperlink are HasHTML, so you can really use whatever HTML snippet you want, including one with an image and some text.

As for your code (which makes it easier to use and makes your whole app more consistent as to how your image is displayed), I'd rather use img.getElement().getStyle().setVerticalAlignment(VerticalAlign.MIDDLE)than your setAttribute("style") technique (well, actually, I'd even rather use a CSS class); and the DOM class will soon be deprecated in favor of the Node and Element's own methods. Finally, you don't have to instantiate an Image widget, you can just use AbstractImagePrototype.create(imageResource).createElement() which is a bit lghter-weight.

entry.content:
@Juri,

Apparently, HTML Option items cannot have an OnClick event. So to get around this, I placed the OnClick attribute in the main RadioButtonList tag as normal and coded it as follows to grab the appropriate input (http://bit.ly/9SfLLl):

var list = document.getElementById("produceDDL");
var inputs = list.getElementsByTagName("input");

var selected;
for (var i = 0; i < inputs.length; i++)
{
if (inputs[i].checked)
{
selected = inputs[i];
break;
}
}
//alert(selected.value);

Ironically, I had to revert to server-side handling (in my case) in order to make this Web-Accessible when JavaScript is disabled.

Hi, guys!
Here is another one (inspired by author...
entry.content:
Hi, guys!

Here is another one (inspired by author's "MyMap extends MapView" class) solution for the described problem with MapView long touch event:

public class ShowMapActivity extends MapActivity {

...

private long touchActionDownStartTime;

...

@Override
public boolean dispatchTouchEvent(MotionEvent ev) {

int actionType = ev.getAction();
if (touchActionDownStartTime > 0 && ev.getEventTime()-touchActionDownStartTime > 1000) {
Toast.makeText(this, "Long push", 1000).show();
touchActionDownStartTime = 0;
}
switch (actionType) {
case MotionEvent.ACTION_DOWN:
touchActionDownStartTime = ev.getEventTime();
case MotionEvent.ACTION_UP:
touchActionDownStartTime = 0;
}
return super.dispatchTouchEvent(ev);
}

...
}

I must admit it is the simplest one solution )
